Vorozhtsov Novosibirsk Institute of Organic Chemistry SB RAS 9 Lavrentieva Ave. Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Graphical abstract The mechanism of ethylene polymerization on phenoxy-imine (FI) titanium catalysts was studied theoretically to identify the major factors affecting the catalytic activity. Geometry optimizations of FI ligands, octahedral titanium dichloride complexes, active cationic species, and their π‐complexes with ethylene as well as calculations of the energy profile of chain propagation were performed at the BP86-D3 level. We found that the calculated energy gaps between frontier orbitals (HOMO and LUMO) in the active cations of the catalysts correlate with the experimental activity values. High activities of FI catalysts with α‐Cumyl groups were attributed to smaller HOMO-LUMO gaps due to hyperconjugation between π-systems of α‐Cumyl and (N‐aryl)salicylaldimine moieties in the active cations. The correlation provides a qualitative estimate of the catalytic activity for further design of new FI titanium complexes. Keywords Phenoxy-imine FI catalyst Ethylene polymerization Catalytic activity DFT 1 Introduction Novel polyolefinic materials, e.g. ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene (UHMWPE), attract the attention of both scientists and engineers due to many useful properties, namely, light weight, excellent mechanical strength, chemical inertness, flexibility, resistance to abrasion, and recyclability. Moreover, UHMWPE is an inexpensive and commercially available substance. These features make it a competitive raw material for manufacture of various valuable products, such as ship ropes, biological prostheses, bullet-proof vests and helmets, protective gloves, car bumpers, and artificial ice [1,2]. Nowadays UHMWPE is mostly prepared by coordination polymerization of ethylene on three main types of catalysts: Ziegler-Natta, metallocene, and post-metallocene [3]. Homogeneous single-site catalytic systems based on phenoxy-imine (FI) titanium dichloride complexes of the post-metallocene type with methylalumoxane (MAO) as a cocatalyst were reported to show high activity in olefin polymerization [4]. The chemical structure of such complexes facilitates the synthesis of a large variety of catalysts, that in turn allows for preparation of UHMWPE of various molecular weight distribution, structure, and morphology [3,5]. Recent studies by Ivanchev et al. [6–10] revealed that FI titanium catalysts bearing a double bond in the ligand structure are capable of self-immobilization during ethylene polymerization. This process results in special morphological features of the resulting PE and thereby makes the product recyclable by a cold gel-formation procedure [11]. Furthermore, Fujita et al. [12–15] demonstrated that the use of FI catalysts with ortho-fluorinated N‐aryl groups allows to perform olefin polymerization in controlled “living” mode and thus to synthesize polymers of various well-defined architectures. Such modifications in the structure of a FI ligand primarily affect catalytic activity and molecular weight distribution of the resulting polymer [3]. In many cases nontrivial organic syntheses of the catalysts as well as numerous polymerization experiments and characterization assays of final polymers are required to find out how these parameters vary for different complexes. Thus, a simple method for estimation of activity and molecular weight distribution without any chemical experiments would be a powerful tool for design of new active FI catalysts. Many studies have been conducted on correlations between experimental values of catalytic activities in ethylene polymerization and theoretical quantum chemical parameters. Remarkable results in this field have been obtained by Cruz and co-workers [16–20] who applied the 3D‐QSAR approach to research into single-site polymerization catalysts of both the metallocene and the post-metallocene type. The authors established relations for quantitative evaluation of both catalytic activity and polymer molecular weight with a high degree of accuracy. The strong predictive power of the proposed method can be associated with thorough consideration of structural aspects in both steric and electronic effects of a ligand. In recent studies, Sun et al. [21–24] demonstrated that activity values for post-metallocene catalysts with late transition metals can be quantitatively predicted using hybrid DFT-QEq calculations. In these works, apart from initial complexes, correlations were determined for active species formed during the polymerization process. These results are of special interest since it is well-known that the initial form of a post-metallocene catalyst by itself cannot perform ethylene polymerization, and the structure of the active species in general differs considerably from that of the pre-catalyst. Within the framework of the “ligand-oriented concept,” Fujita et al. [25] found correlation between experimental activity of FI catalysts and electronic flexibility of the ligand which in turn was determined by the energies of frontier orbitals (HOMO and LUMO) in the ligand structure calculated at the MNDO-PM3 level. Employing MM‐QEq calculations, HuaYi and co-workers [26] evaluated the influence of the metal net charge in a large number of FI titanium and zirconium dichloride complexes. Although structure-activity relations in these studies had more qualitative nature, both research groups came to the conclusion that electron-withdrawing groups in the ligand of a complex are favorable for high activity in ethylene polymerization under mild conditions. In the present work, we theoretically analyze the mechanism of ethylene polymerization on FI titanium dichloride complexes and establish correlations for qualitative estimation of the catalytic activity values by means of DFT calculations of active cationic species and related structures. 2 Computational methods All computations were performed using the ORCA 3.0.3 software package [27] on a parallel platform of the LUNARC center for high-performance computing [21]. Optimal parameters for the calculations (the DFT functional and the basis set) were chosen after a comparison of optimized geometries of dichloride complexes with the corresponding experimental X‐ray structures (see Supporting information). The geometry optimizations were performed with BP86 exchange-correlation functional and SVP split-valence basis set for all atoms [28–30]. In the case of energy barrier calculations, the D3BJ atom-pairwise dispersion correction with Becke-Johnson damping was added to the functional, and the basis set was extended to TZVP. In order to confirm the type of stationary points (minima or transition states), eigenvalues of the numerical hessian were computed. For assessment of the solvent effect in the energy barrier calculations (for single point energies) we utilizied the COSMO continuum solvation model [31]. Natural population analysis was performed in the JANPA 1.02 software [32]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The calculated structures of FI titanium catalysts For our computations we selected a series of FI titanium catalysts 1–21 that were previously used for ethylene polymerization by Ivanchev and Fujita and co-workers (Fig. 1 ) [6–10,33–36]. The series includes two complete sets containing nine dichloride complexes with α‐tBu and α‐Cumyl [2‐(2‐phenylpropyl)] substituents in the ligand structure (1–18). Each set includes six self-immobilizing catalysts with an allyloxy group (OAll) in the N‐aryl moiety. Such sets were chosen to find a theoretical explanation of the higher catalytic activities of FI titanium and zirconium dichloride complexes bearing α‐Cumyl substituents as compared to their α‐tBu analogs. This phenomenon was previously attributed to higher steric bulkiness of α‐Cumyl(s) as compared with α‐tBu(s) [37,40]. Here, we show that the electronic structure of an α‐Cumyl group is also responsible for high activities of the corresponding catalysts. In order to evaluate the impact of the steric effect and the “living” character of the polymerization on the activity, we also analyzed two FI titanium catalysts with α‐1‐(4‐(tert‐butyl)phenyl)ethyl substituents (19, 20) and one with ortho‐fluorinated N‐aryl groups (21). Note that, since the accurate structure-activity relation was not the aim of this work, we used activity values that were measured under close but not exactly the same experimental conditions (see Supporting information). For some catalysts, due to the lack of the necessary experimental data, the activities were estimated from two closest temperature points. It is well-known that catalytic activity is strongly affected by polymerization conditions. Nonetheless, we believe that for qualitative relations between experimental and theoretical data, which are the aim of this work, the accuracy of the estimated values is acceptable. 3.2 Analysis of the polymerization mechanism The time-averaged activity of FI titanium catalysts 1–21 in ethylene polymerization measured by Ivanchev [6–10,34] and Fujita et al. [3,12–15,25,37–40] is defined as (1) a c t i v i t y = ¯ M C 2 H 4 ∫ 0 τ W p ( t ) d t C T i p C 2 H 4 τ , where M C 2 H 4 and p C 2 H 4 denote the molecular weight and the pressure of ethylene, respectively; c Ti − the initial concentration of a catalyst, τ − polymerization time; and W p ( t ) is the propagation rate given by (2) W p = k eff [ Ti ] act [ C 2 H 4 ] , where k eff is the effective rate constant (activity of a single active site), and [ Ti ] act and [ C 2 H 4 ] denote concentrations of active sites and ethylene, respectively. Assuming that the polymerization process is carried out under the same conditions, the catalytic activity should be determined by a composite function of k eff [ Ti ] act . In order to estimate contributions of different chemical interactions into the activity of FI catalysts 1–21 in ethylene polymerization, we proposed a model of the mechanism starting from octahedral titanium dichloride complexes (Fig. 2 ). Note that the real mechanism can be more complicated and in general depends on the composition of a catalytic system [3]. Nevertheless, it always contains three main stages that are listed in Fig. 2. The first activation stage results in formation of an active site (AC0 ) from an initial titanium complex (IC). As shown previously [3,41–44], the active site has cationic nature and exists in the medium predominantly in the form of an ionic pair (IP0 ) with a large molecule of a cocatalyst. This stage is often assumed to be rapid and quantitative in the polymerization [45]. Thus, it does not affect the activity of FI catalysts 1–21 significantly. The next propagation reaction depicted in Fig. 2 plays a key role in the activity of FI complexes because it involves an elementary stage where the monomer is consumed. The monomer consumption at this stage was experimentally proven by Bryliakov with co‐workers [44]. The last termination stage can be subdivided into two types depending on whether it results in a decrease of the active site concentration. The active termination is presented in our model by means of two β‐hydrogen transfer reactions from a polymeric chain to a metal center and to a monomer moiety. As demonstrated theoretically by Villani et al. [46], these two types of H‐transfer have the biggest contribution to the active termination. Since the number of active sites does not change after both reactions, their influence on the activity is also negligible. The inactive termination results in a decrease in the concentration of active cations (ACn ). Therefore, this stage always lessens the final activity of a catalyst. The mechanism underlying such deactivation is not clear, but it is believed to include a ligand transfer from the FI catalyst to a molecule of the cocatalyst [3,44]. It is then not surprising that sterically hindered substituents in the ligand structure are favorable for highly active catalysts because they reduce the contribution of the deactivation reaction, i.e. make the active site more stable. In the present work, for the sake of the simplicity we omit the active cation isomerization described previously [42,47] and perform calculations of all chemical species and transition states for the N,N‐cis‐O,O‐trans diastereomer that has the lowest energy among all other isomers [48]. On the whole, besides the deactivation reaction, only the propagation stage notably affects the activity of FI titanium catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2, the propagation reaction includes three elementary stages: dissociation of ionic pairs (IPn) into active cationic (ACn) species, π‐complex (PCn) formation, and ethylene insertion into the polymeric chain. The last stage is followed by association of the formed cation with a cocatalyst anion and is assumed to be identical to the reverse first stage. The dissociation of ionic pairs affects the number of active sites in the polymerization ( [ Ti ] act , Eq. (2)), whereas the second and third elementary stages determine the activity of a single active site ( k eff , Eq. (2)). We calculated the energy profile for the last two stages of chain propagation to identify the rate- k eff limiting reaction and chemical species whose structures mostly affect the effective constant keff . Fig. 3 and Table 1 show changes in energy in the course of one step of the propagation reaction during ethylene polymerization on FI catalyst 3. As seen both in vacuum and in toluene, the transition state TS2 has higher free energy than TS1 does. This means that the third elementary stage (monomer insertion into the attached polymeric chain) represents the highest energy barrier in the chain propagation and therefore this reaction is the rate-limiting stage of the propagation process. Hence, the effective rate constant k eff is determined by the difference in free energy between reagents (AC1 + C2H4 ) and the transition state TS2 (see Supporting information for details). It should also be noted that activation barriers (ΔG0 ) for both elementary stages are small, in accordance with the catalytic nature of the reaction. Moreover, a solvent correction for free energies can be well associated with the entropic term ( ‐TΔS0 ). More substantial system reorganization at the second stage results in a greater impact of the solvent effect on energy. At both elementary stages enthalpic and entropic terms make opposite contributions into the free energy. Nonetheless, the formation energy of a weak coordinate bond between ethylene and titanium cannot account for the entropic term at the second stage. Consequently, the highly exothermic formation of two strong σ‐bonds in the third elementary reaction serves as the driving force behind the propagation process. 3.3 Correlations between experimental activity values and theoretical data The dissociation of ionic pairs into active cationic species and the π‐complex formation in the propagation reaction directly depend on the structure of the active site and cocatalyst (Fig. 2). According to Fukui basic principle of the nature of chemical reactions [49], the first stage in the propagation reaction is controlled by Coulomb, exchange, and orbital interaction terms. The contribution of each term depends on the structure of the cocatalyst. For instance, in the case of a weakly coordinating anion B(C6F5)4 −, the exchange and orbital interactions are negligible. Unfortunately, for methylalumoxane (MAO) used with the FI titanium catalysts that were studied in the works of Ivanchev and Fujita et al. [6–10,33–36] it is difficult to calculate the contributions of each term becasuse the cocatalyst presents a complex mixture of chemical compounds whose structures are unclear [50]. Nevertheless, Flisak et al. [51] estimated the impact of the Coulomb interaction at 70% for the counterion binding to MeB(C6F5)3 −, which has a structure similar (in the sense of binding) to that of oligomers of MAO. Assuming that the Coulomb interaction makes a major contribution to the dissociation of ionic pairs of the catalysts, the main differences at this stage can be attributed to various charge distribution in the active cation and the steric effect. Here, we estimated the first term as differences in the Mulliken atomic charge on titanium in optimized structures of active cations formed from initial FI dichloride complexes 1–21. Table 2 shows experimentally measured activities [6–10,33–36] and the calculated HOMO-LUMO gaps as well, as the Mulliken atomic charges (MAC) on titanium for catalysts 1–21. One can see that except for “living” catalyst 21, variation of MAC for all complexes in question is very small. A notable difference in the atomic net charge on titanium for complex 21 can be attributed to a special structure of its active cation with an intramolecular attractive interaction between α‐fluorine of an N‐aryl moiety and β‐hydrogen of the growing polymeric chain (Fig. 4 , left). Coulomb energy of this interaction is thought to be −7kJ/mol, which is still consistent with other theoretical and experimental data [53,54]. Thus, the major differences in the number of active sites in ethylene polymerization on “nonliving” FI catalysts 1–20 can be ascribed to the steric effect. As shown in Fig. 2, the third elementary stage in the propagation reaction involves the early transition state TS2 whose electronic structure is then similar to π-complex PC1 . Within the framework of the Fukui theory, the interaction between a neutral molecule of ethylene and a positively charged active cation yielding a π-complex is mostly controlled by the polarization term, i.e. by the energy gap between HOMO and LUMO (Fig. 5 ). Table 2 shows that the variation of HOMO-LUMO gap values reaches 11%. in optimized structures for active cations formed from corresponding FI dichloride complexes 1–20. Overall, we can conclude that the steric effect and the electronic structure of the active cationic species (determined by their HOMO-LUMO gaps) should be the major factors affecting activities of FI catalysts 1–20. In order to confirm this conclusion, we plotted experimentally measured activities of catalysts 1–20 in ethylene polymerization versus theoretically calculated inversed HOMO-LUMO gap values for cationic species formed from the corresponding dichloride complexes in the polymerization process. Fig. 6 clearly shows that there is a good correlation (R 2 =0.54) between experimental and theoretical data for complexes with α‐tBu and α‐Cumyl substituents in the ligand structure (1–18). The data on “living” catalyst 21 are as expected out of this correlation because of a special structure of its active cation (Fig. 4, left). Comparing the data obtained for FI catalysts 1–18 and 19–20, we can draw the conclusion that the steric hindrance of α‐tBu substituents and hindrance of α‐Cumyl substituents are similar and greater than that of the α‐1‐(4‐(tert‐butyl)phenyl)ethyl group. This state of affair results in higher activities of complexes 3 and 12 as compared with their analog 20 in spite of a smaller HOMO-LUMO gap in the active cation 20 (Table 2). Interestingly, self-immobilizing catalysts belong to the same correlation as the corresponding complexes without an allyloxy group in the N‐aryl moiety. This means that the influence of self-immobilization on the activity of the FI catalysts in question is less significant than the steric effect or the “living” character of the polymerization. Furthermore, the established correlation explains why FI titanium catalysts with α‐Cumyl substituents are more active in ethylene polymerization than their α‐tBu analogs. Gathering the electron density on their atoms, α‐Cumyl groups delocalize HOMO of the cationic species and thereby make it more diffusive (Fig. 7 , left). This phenomenon leads to an increase in HOMO energy (a decrease in the HOMO-LUMO gap, Fig. 5) and finally causes an increase in a growth of their catalytic activity in the polymerization (Table 2). It is also worth noting that, using the Koopmans theorem [55,56], one can easily determine the correlation between the inversed value of the HOMO-LUMO gap and Pearson’s chemical softness [57] as (3) S = 2 I − A ≈ 2 ε LUMO − ε HOMO = 2 gap , where I and A denote the ionization potential and the electron affinity, respectively. As a consequence, higher activity of FI catalysts (whose active cations have smaller HOMO-LUMO gaps) correlates with well-known Pearson’s HSAB principle [58]. Being a soft base, ethylene tends to react with softer active cations that are classified as Pearson’s acids. On the other hand, according to Parr’s principle of maximum hardness [59], a decrease in the HOMO-LUMO gap leads to an increase in the overall chemical reactivity of the active cation. Hence, sterically hindered substituents in the FI ligand structure are favorable for catalysts highly active in ethylene polymerization because such substituents increase the kinetic stability of the active site. Note that this result was also observed in the experiments of Ivanchev and Fujita with their co‐workers. [35,37,40,52,60]. 3.4 Correlations between theoretical data for different chemical species in ethylene polymerization Quantum chemical calculations of a large molecule of an active cation appear to be time-consuming and resource-intensive. Moreover, active cations are much more labile chemical compounds than the initial titanium dichloride complexes. At this point, computations on small FI ligands or octahedral titanium dichloride complexes for correlations with experimental data seem more attractive. On the other hand, Fig. 8 shows that the calculated HOMO-LUMO gaps for active FI titanium cations correlate neither with the ones for FI ligands nor with those for the octahedral dichloride complexes. As a result there is no correlation between theoretical and experimental data for ligands and dichloride complexes (see Supporting information). It is then difficult to estimate activity of FI titanium catalysts from quantum chemical calculations of these species. On the contrary, there is a rather strong correlation between the calculated gap values for active cations and their π‐complexes with ethylene. This means that the propagation reaction can be considered a small perturbation in the electronic structure of the active site during the polymerization. This finding also supports that the Fukui theory [49] may be used for estimation of the interaction energy between ethylene and an active cation from calculated HOMO-LUMO gap values. 4 Conclusions The mechanism of ethylene polymerization on FI titanium catalysts has been studied by means of the density functional theory. We found that the propagation reaction has a strong influence on activity of the catalysts. Calculations of the energy profile of the chain propagation have revealed that ethylene insertion into the attached polymeric chain determines the effective activity of a single active site in the polymerization. Both the electronic and steric effect of the ligand determine the total catalytic activity. The major factor affecting the activity of FI titanium catalysts depends on the structure of the active site. For FI titanium dichloride complexes with α‐tBu and α‐Cumyl substituents, experimentally determined activity values correlate with the calculated HOMO-LUMO gaps in active cationic species. We showed that α‐Cumyl groups in a FI ligand stabilize the active cation making it more sterically hindered. On the other hand, these groups increase electronic flexibility of the cation via hyperconjugation with the π‐system of aryl moieties, thereby making the catalysts more active in the ethylene polymerization. The DFT calculations allow for estimation of changes in the electronic structure of FI titanium complexes caused by addition of new substituents to aryl moieties. Therefore they can be useful for the design of new highly active catalysts for ethylene polymerization. Nevertheless, our estimates have qualitative nature, and further studies are needed for more accurate prediction of the catalytic activity. coredata.dc:description: The mechanism of ethylene polymerization on phenoxy-imine (FI) titanium catalysts was studied theoretically to identify the major factors affecting the catalytic activity. Geometry optimizations of FI ligands, octahedral titanium dichloride complexes, active cationic species, and their π‐complexes with ethylene as well as calculations of the energy profile of chain propagation were performed at the BP86-D3 level. We found that the calculated energy gaps between frontier orbitals (HOMO and LUMO) in the active cations of the catalysts correlate with the experimental activity values. High activities of FI catalysts with α‐Cumyl groups were attributed to smaller HOMO-LUMO gaps due to hyperconjugation between π-systems of α‐Cumyl and (N‐aryl)salicylaldimine moieties in the active cations. The correlation provides a qualitative estimate of the catalytic activity for further design of new FI titanium complexes.
coredata.dc:title: Activity of phenoxy-imine titanium catalysts in ethylene polymerization: A quantum chemical approach
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
